prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 depicts each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent individuals, and the connections are weighted to reflect social contact that could lead to infection based on the edge weight (a probability value between 0 and 1). The first layer shows home interactions, where groups of varying sizes are fully connected internally with no external connections, representing individual families. The size distribution of Peruvian families in 2009 is utilized to create these groups, taking into account the probability of family sizes ranging from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of any country's population engages in work or economic activities, which involves social interactions. Work is a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To simulate work activity, a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Peru's total population, is proposed. This layer reflects a common scenario with random groups ranging from 5 to 30 individuals, internally connected like the "home" layer. An example of this layer is illustrated in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. Public transportation plays a vital role in cities but poses a risk for virus transmission due to crowded conditions and constant movement. A third layer is introduced to represent public transport users, accounting for an average of 50% of the population in Peru. Groups of varying sizes between 10 and 40 are randomly created for this layer, with fully connected nodes. The impact of edge weights on virus transmission within these layers is discussed in Section 3.1.1. The use of public transport varies based on city size in Peru, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities, averaging 1.2 hours daily. This study considers a sample of 50% of the population between these cases for the "transports" layer.
original_pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 Fig. 2. Each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes are people and do not change across layers, and the weighted connections represent social contact which may lead to infection according to the edge weight (probability value within [0, 1)). The first layer represents home interactions and is composed of a set of groups with varying sizes, which are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, i.e., the network starts with disconnected components representing each family. To create each group, we consider the Brazilian family size distribution for 2010 [22], the year with more detailed information on family sizes from 1 up to 14 members. We consider the probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), a multi-layer network model is presented where each social layer is represented by nodes that are people and weighted connections that signify social contact with the potential for infection depending on the edge weight (a probability value between 0 and 1). The first layer depicts home interactions and consists of groups of various sizes that are fully connected internally, representing families with different sizes based on the Colombian family size distribution for 2010. Each family is ensured to have at least one adult. Another layer is constructed to represent work interactions for individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of the population. This layer illustrates the significant role of work in social relations, particularly in the context of an epidemic.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .The connectivity of a group's nodes is important for the transmission of the virus, with the edge weights being a key factor discussed in detail in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation in cities is crucial but can also be a hotspot for spreading epidemics due to high population density and constant movement of vehicles. In our model, we introduce a layer representing public transportation, which includes individuals who do not have access to a personal vehicle. In Colombia, the percentage of people using public transport varies depending on the city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging about 1.2 hours per day. To simulate this layer, we randomly select 50% of the population to participate in groups of sizes ranging from 10 to 40, with nodes fully connected within each group. This approach accounts for the average usage patterns observed across different cities in Colombia. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a recent study by eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498, the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy rates. The study utilized a social network model with initial infection probabilities, starting at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree. The infection spread over 300 days in daily iterations, with an initial infection probability (β < 1) reflecting a scenario of early awareness and social distancing measures. A moderate quarantine was applied after 27 days, reducing contact rates to 30% of their initial values. The study found that higher β values led to faster disease spread and higher overall cases and deaths, while natural immunization of recovered individuals helped end the epidemic sooner. These findings were consistent with the progression of the pandemic in Argentina.

Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be due to increased testing in Argentina or a decrease in isolation levels in the country. We used a fixed isolation level based on the early days after government decrees, but data indicates that isolation levels are constantly changing. This suggests that the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may be higher than reported in the paper. Daily death toll estimates from the model are higher than official numbers, which could be due to underdetection rates and limited testing. Analysis of death numbers in Argentina from January to April shows a clear increase after the first confirmed case of COVID-19, suggesting the actual death toll may be higher than reported. Moving forward, we consider four possible actions after 90 days: maintaining current isolation levels, ending isolation completely, only returning work activities, or increasing isolation by stopping work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
original_post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

The standard deviation is shown by the dotted lines, while the solid lines represent the raw data. The high average number of deaths from the model may be due to underdetection (see Fig. 5). In Fig. 5, the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Peru was analyzed by comparing death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same period (January 1 to April 30). The discrepancy between total deaths and official COVID-19 records suggests significant underdetection. Upon resuming all activities after considering growth, peak, and decline, there would be an estimated 1,253,119 (± 26,009) diagnosed cases and 197,756 (± 5,693) deaths. Implementing a strict 90-day lockdown would decrease infection and death rates significantly compared to other measures. The recovery time is also faster, with daily new cases stopping earlier in this scenario. The peak of daily new cases is projected to occur on day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths on day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there would be approximately 552,855 (± 195,802) diagnosed cases and 87,059 (± 30,871) deaths. Using the hospitalization time outlined in Fig. 3, we can estimate the number of occupied beds for regular and critical cases. Additionally, the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases alongside recoveries is also shown.

Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three potential scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) maintaining current isolation levels (no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and transport), (b) ending isolation (returning to normal with schools, religious gatherings, work, and transport), or (c) increasing isolation (halting work and public transport). post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days since the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented which included halting schools and religious activities while maintaining work and transportation at 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. After 90 days, different options were considered such as maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation measures, completely ending isolation and resuming all activities, or only returning work activities. Results indicate that maintaining current isolation levels would result in a prolonged outbreak with an estimated peak around June 5, averaging 11,000 new daily cases and 1900 deaths. By the end of the year, there could be 946,830 diagnosed cases (potentially 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may reach capacity by June 11, but with proper logistics and the addition of new ICU beds, the situation could still be controlled. However, this optimistic scenario relies on maintaining social isolation levels above 50%, which has been a challenge in Argentina where levels have consistently been at 12%.

After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. In this scenario, hospitals may exceed its maximum capacity around June 11. However, the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistic management of patients may still keep the situation under control. However, this is a very optimistic assumption, considering that our definition of ''keep isolation'' considers social isolation above 50% as registered at the beginning of the Brazilian quarantine [43]. author: chunwei
pre_context:
L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. studied the effects of different scenarios on the total number of infected and recovered cases and the utilization of hospital beds after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or increasing isolation by stopping work and public transport. Testing limitations were taken into account, with only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases were not detected and continued to spread in the network. Assumptions were made about infected nodes isolating themselves at home if they had mild symptoms and severe cases being hospitalized and fully isolated to prevent further spread.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers analyzed three possible scenarios for the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing capacity was limited due to a low number of tests and the rapid spread of the virus. As a result, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus unknowingly. 6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios mentioned earlier, Maximum Infected Values were obtained by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic Scenario 1 where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the effects of enforcing mask wearing on different timeframes: (a) on the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Hong Kong; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) no enforcement at all. The results show that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this maximum. The Infected compartment shifts rightwards and the peak value of infected cases decreases. The infected numbers rise until they reach the Maximum Infected Value before declining, as expected from this type of compartmental modeling.

Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing Upon applying the SEIR models to the 3 scenarios described in the above sections, we are able to obtain Maximum Infected Values by simulating different values of delay in mask enforcement. Considering the most basic case of Scenario 1; where there is complete compliance throughout the duration of mask enforcement, and the absence of time-limited immunity, Figure 3 shows the cases where mask wearing were to be enforced (a) on the day the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Singapore; (b) after a 50 days delay; (c) after a 100 days delay; and (d) not enforced at all. From Figure 3, it can be deduced that earlier enforcement of mask wearing both reduces the Maximum Infected Value as well as increases the number of days taken to reach the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. author: chunwei
pre_context:
Mortality rate refers to the percentage of deaths among individuals who were previously infected. In this study, there were 26 deaths in Malaysia out of a total of 40,625 in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to the unpredictable nature of mortality rates across different demographics and the small number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia, an accurate average cannot be obtained. As a result, for analysis purposes, a mortality rate of 1/9 (approximately 9 days) was used.

Results and Discussion:

The SEIR models were applied to three scenarios to assess the impact of delaying compulsory mask wearing. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, simulations were conducted with different delays in mask enforcement. The results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also extends the time it takes to reach this maximum. This is evident from the rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment and lower maximum values of the infected curve in Figure 3. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.

post_context:
[25].In order to assess the impact of delaying the enforcement of public mask usage on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers related to the B117 variant, we conducted a hypothetical modeling scenario. We assumed that the first case of COVID-19 in Singapore was the B117 variant, and adjusted our simulation accordingly. The results are depicted in Figures 6 and 7, showing the maximum infection rates based on the delay in mask enforcement for different scenarios. 
When comparing our study to similar research conducted by Eikenberry et al. [3], it is noted that they also used mathematical modelling to analyze the effects of delayed mask enforcement. However, their study focused on the US states of New York and Washington, while ours specifically looked at Singapore. Our study takes into account factors like the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, providing a more accurate representation for smaller city states like Singapore. This highlights the importance of considering differences in epidemiological parameters and characteristics when studying the impact of public health interventions.

original_post_context: [25]. To investigate the impact of delay in public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers due to the B117 variant, we modelled a hypothetical scenario. In this scenario, the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant. We ran our simulation of the 3 scenarios described in the preceding sections with a new value of R0 reflecting that of B117. The resulting plots are shown in Figure 6 and 7. Figure 6. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case. Figure 7. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance for the B117 variant case. 6.3. Related Studies Juxtaposing our study against other similar studies that implement mathematical modelling on 'what-if' scenario based analysis, Eikenberry et al. [3] implemented a compartmentalized models for their simulations, and concluded that if the population remains unmasked until mask enforcement after some discrete delay, and that the level of adoption is fixed, the delay initially had little impact on the hospitalized fraction or deaths, but states that a 'point of no return' can be crossed. While this study yields similar results to ours, it is contextualised in the US states of New York and Washington, whilst ours was conducted in the context of Singapore. Given the differences in epidemiological parameters, size and characteristics of these cities and Singapore, our study adds value in being a more accurate representation of smaller city states. Furthermore, this study did not take into consideration newer, more infectious strains of the virus such as the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, which we have considered in our study.

The study was conducted at the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China, the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada, and the School of Mathematics and Information Science at Shaanxi Normal University in China.School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Hubei, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures. The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the
post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Hubei on infections in Beijing is comparable to a 100 thousand increase in quarantine measures. The effectiveness and duration of costly interventions by the Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections need to be evaluated. The outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks under strict measures, with a significant decrease in peak infections. Implementing travel restrictions can reduce the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% in one week compared to no restrictions. Key words: coronavirus; infection management control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model. Coronaviruses are RNA viruses that have caused major outbreaks, including SARS in 2003 in China, MERS in 2012 in Saudi Arabia, and MERS in 2015 in South Korea.

Sensitivity analyses show that interventions, such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation, can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk, with the effect of travel restriction adopted by Wuhan on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing being almost equivalent to increasing quarantine by a 100 thousand baseline value. It is essential to assess how the expensive, resource-intensive measures implemented by the Chinese authorities can contribute to the prevention and control of the 2019-nCoV infection, and how long they should be maintained. Introduction Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the family of Coronaviridae [1]. They cause generally mild respiratory infections, even though they are occasionally lethal. Since their discovery and first characterization in 1965 [2], three major, large-scale outbreaks have occurred, caused by emerging, highly pathogenic coronaviruses, namely, the "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome" (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in mainland China [3], the "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome" (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia [4,5] and the MERS outbreak in 2015 in South J. post_context:
.As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital resulting in R(0) = 2, while 739 individuals were quarantined with Sq(0) = 739. Setting H(0) = 1, representing the confirmed case on January 10, 2020. The quarantined individuals remained isolated for 14 days, making λ = 1/14. The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is around 7 days, leading to σ = 1/7.

Likelihood-based estimation of Rc in the Nanchang outbreak yielded a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of generation time set at 6 and 2 days based on revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number varies from 1.66 to 10 and is affected by changes in mean generation intervals. Another analysis using revised data series (dataRev2) resulted in a mean value of 6.32 with a mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days. Both sets of estimates of Rc aligned closely, allowing for the use of either series to fit the proposed transmission model. This study selected estimates from dataRev1 as the comparison reference to validate the model-based estimation. Consequently, the following sections of the manuscript will utilize the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

The formula used for estimation is L(Rc, p|N) = T(cid:89) t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where k is the maximum value of the serial interval (set as 6 in this case) and Γ(x) represents the gamma function. N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT}, with Nj indicating the total number of cases on day j and T being the last day of observations. As the generation interval for the 2019-nCoV is unknown, we examined the impact of different mean values ranging from 2 to 8 days on the estimation of Rc. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

The formula used to calculate the basic reproduction number (Rc) for 2019-nCoV in Fangcang shelter, China involves various parameters such as the generation interval probability function (pj) and the gamma distribution of the generation interval with mean (E) and variance (V). The sensitivity of Rc to different mean values of the generation interval (ranging from 2 to 8 days) was investigated to assess the impact on the estimation of Rc. Simulation was done using data on the population of Fangcang shelter, number of recovered patients, individuals quarantined, and confirmed cases to model the spread of the virus. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7.

original_post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23), in comparison with = 4.91) in Beijing, China, in 2003 [26], and MERS in Jeddah the values of the SARS epidemics (R0 (R0 = 3.5–6.7) and Riyadh (R0 Our value is higher than other published estimates (for instance, Reference [28]). Such a high reproduction number is consistent with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations of transmission in the period covered by this study [24]. Note that our estimation is based on a dataset collected during a period of intensive social contacts. Before the Chinese New Year (25 January 2020), there were lots of annual summing-up meetings and/or parties, with higher than usual close contacts, leading to a higher likelihood of infection transmission than that of the earlier periods covered by other studies. Furthermore, we noted that more recently published studies based on datasets during periods comparable with ours reported similar findings in terms of a high basic reproduction number (for instance, Reference [29], where authors, using an exponential growth method, computed a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days). Variability in the estimation of the basic reproduction number is also a well-known methodological issue, and standardized methods both for calculating and reporting it are still lacking [30]. During the initial phases of an epidemics outbreak, only small datasets/time-points can be used. Some crucial information may be missing, and the quality, accuracy and reliability of data improves over time. In these situations, estimations are highly dependent on the specific datasets utilized and revising/updating such datasets could influence the results. We note that several key clinical parameters could be inferred from relevant clinical data based on sero-epidemiological surveys, and the possibility of spreading the infection from asymptomatic cases was only reported recently [31]. pre_context: The exponential growth method was used to calculate a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming a constant reporting rate and a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days. Estimating the basic reproduction number can be challenging due to methodological issues, and standardized methods for calculation and reporting are still needed. Initial phases of an epidemic may lack complete data, with information becoming more accurate over time. Estimates are influenced by the specific datasets used, and updating these datasets can impact results. Key clinical parameters can be derived from sero-epidemiological surveys, and the potential for spread from asymptomatic cases has only recently been acknowledged. A high reproduction number suggests a serious epidemic potential without swift public health interventions, especially during peak social contact times. The serial interval greatly impacts likelihood function estimation accuracy. The incubation period for Nanjing coronavirus patients ranges from 2 to 15 days, as reported. We then assume that the serial interval follows the gamma distribution with varying mean and variance, which allows us to examine the influence on the reproduction number. With the distribution of serial interval with mean 6 days and variance 2 days, the likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number is consistent with the model-based estimation. It shows that longer serial intervals induce greater reproduction numbers, and hence, more new infections, which further confirms that the epidemic may be more serious than what has been reported until now [15]. post_context: , as of January 23, 2020. Compared to Nanjing's total population size, the efforts of close contact tracing and quarantine were insufficient and had minimal impact on reducing the number of infected cases or slowing the epidemic. The contour plot of R_c = 1 shows the critical values of contact rate and quarantine rate needed for a city to prevent an outbreak. The high threshold for quarantine places a heavy burden on the city's public health system and requires strict adherence to protective measures by its citizens, including reducing effective contacts, separation, and restrictions during quarantine. Achieving this high level of quarantine and reduced contact is only feasible if imported cases from the epicenter are minimal, emphasizing the importance of travel restrictions. However, imposing strict travel restrictions on Nanjing is costly and resource-intensive, presenting challenges for decision-makers and the city's resilience. Additionally, such measures may only delay the spread of the disease.

Given recent events such as the lock-down of Hubei, adoption of travel restrictions in other regions, and advancements in detection technologies, the current model needs to be updated as the basic reproduction number may no longer accurately predict future epidemic trends. This will be the focus of a forthcoming article. Analysis of predicted and actual confirmed cases suggest that coronaviruses can cause significant outbreaks, with reproduction numbers typically falling within a range of 2.0 to 4.9. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Hubei province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine, and travel restrictions. Conclusions Coronaviruses occasionally lead to major outbreaks, with documented reproduction numbers ranging from 2.0 to 4.9. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Wuhan, Hubei province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine and travel restrictions. original_post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the predicted confirmed cases should be 7723 as of 29 January 2020, which is very close to the real number of cases of 7711. Furthermore, according to our model, the outbreak, under the most restrictive measures, is expected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020), with a significant low peak value. Our investigation has major practical implications for public health decision- and policy-makers. The rather high reproduction number suggests that the outbreak may be more serious than what has been reported so far, given the particular season of increasing social contacts, warranting effective, strict public health measures aimed to mitigate the burden generated by the spreading of the new virus. The recent events such as the lockdown of Hangzhou on January 23, 2020, and the implementation of travel restrictions in various regions and provinces, necessitate a revision of the current epidemic model. The basic reproduction number is no longer sufficient for predicting future trends, as seen in Table 4. A forthcoming article will focus on this revision. The predictions of confirmed cases show the impact of reducing contact by 50% and 90%. Despite the lack of epidemiological data, it is crucial to implement timely public health interventions such as contact tracing, quarantine, and travel restrictions to control the spread of the ongoing coronavirus outbreak originating from Hangzhou, China.

In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that the basic reproduction number could be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the

Moreover, based on our model, we anticipate that the outbreak will reach its peak within two weeks (as of January 23, 2020) even with the strictest measures in place, resulting in a significantly low peak value. This study has crucial implications for public health decision-makers and policymakers. The relatively high reproduction number indicates that the outbreak may be more severe than currently reported, especially during a season of increased social interactions, highlighting the need for strict public health interventions to reduce the impact of the virus spread. Given the ongoing developments related to the outbreak of coronavirus in Chengdu on 23 January 2020, including the implementation of travel restrictions in various regions and the introduction of new detection technologies, it is evident that the current model for predicting epidemic trends needs to be revised. The basic reproduction number previously estimated may no longer be accurate for forecasting future cases, as shown in Table 4. The aim of a forthcoming article will be to reassess this model. The table displays predictions of confirmed cases, with the real data of confirmed cases also included. The lack of epidemiological data on the emerging coronavirus highlights the need for timely and effective public health interventions such as contact tracing, quarantine, and travel restrictions to control the spread of the virus.

In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that the basic reproduction number could be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the predicted confirmed cases should be 7723 as of 29 January 2020, which is very close to the

.

This analysis holds significant implications for public health decision-makers and policymakers. The higher than usual reproduction number indicates the outbreak's potential severity, especially during a season of increased social interactions, necessitating strict public health measures to mitigate the impact of the new virus. author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with greater air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The uneven distribution of the population in the state, combined with spatial attributes like transport connectivity, contributed to variations in the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic among counties. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties (Ohio, Williamson County, Grayson, Birmingham, and Peak), with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving millions of passengers each year. The airports in these counties can lead to a high influx of locally imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus in these areas. (Organization, 2020; Warren et al., 2010). In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . However, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural and less connected counties, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities, our modeling shows that the lower transmission rates in these areas have prevented critical care saturation. If non-pharmaceutical interventions continue after early May, only 27% of the state's critical care capacity would be reached, excluding the 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. Another three counties, Clermont, Delaware, and Lawrence, would exceed 50% capacity. In contrast, easing interventions by 50% would result in 61% capacity reached after eight weeks, with faster saturation for areas with intense transmission. These counties, while having higher capacity, would reach 94% capacity within the same time frame. Conversely, rural and less connected counties in Group 4 would experience slower infection spread, mitigating critical care strain.

Despite these local differences in the critical healthcare capacity of the state, our modeling results suggest that the differential local dynamics of the disease, with substantially  less  transmission  in  these  rural  and  less  connected counties, prevented the saturation of the critical care response in these areas. pre_context: The adjusted model revealed that the differences in COVID-19 severity among counties in Indiana were not solely due to population distribution, but also factors such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Marion, Allen, Lake, St. Joseph, and Vanderburgh) with a high infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The airports in these counties can introduce locally imported infections, increasing local virus transmission and accelerating infection spread. On the other hand, infection rates were lower in rural and less connected counties in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Indiana, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite varying healthcare capacities across the state, our modeling shows that rural and less connected counties experienced significantly lower transmission rates, preventing critical care response saturation. Continuing non-pharmaceutical interventions beyond early May could result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being reached, particularly in counties without ICU beds like Hamilton, Johnson, and Marion. However, easing interventions by 50% could lead to 61% capacity being reached after eight weeks, with areas of intense transmission saturating faster. Counties in Group 1, despite having higher capacity, would see 94% saturation if interventions are eased. In contrast, slower spread in rural counties in Group 4 would minimize impact on critical care response.

author: enrique
pre_context: It is forecasted that by the end of 2021, approximately 680,000 people will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of them showing no symptoms. The highest spikes in new cases are expected in December 2019 and March 2020. By the end of the year, it is projected that 71% of the Ontario population will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, and 57% will be fully vaccinated. Of the estimated 11,000 COVID-related deaths, 36% will be attributed to the wild type, 47% to the Alpha variant, and 17% to the Delta variant. These predictions are in line with actual reported data for Ontario in 2021. The drop in the number of susceptible individuals is noticeable starting from December 2019, mainly due to the vaccination campaign. By the end of June 2020, only 37% of the population will still be susceptible, with most having received at least one vaccine dose. The peak in active infections is expected by the end of 2019, followed by an even higher peak in the spring, driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. As vaccination rates increase, the number of Alpha-driven infections decreases. Approximately half of the infections are expected to be asymptomatic, with the majority of those affected being unvaccinated. The percentage of the population that has recovered from the virus is anticipated to be 7% by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. post_context: affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease.Due to the significant impact of health care infrastructure on COVID-19 mortality rates, we adjusted μW I by 50%. Changes in this parameter directly affected the number of deaths, but the mortality rate had a relatively small effect on the overall infected population, as less than 5% of them died. Various provincial policies and interventions, such as non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI), vaccination rates, dosing intervals, and vaccine escape rates, were considered. NPI had a large impact on model predictions, while vaccination rates also played a significant role in controlling the spread of the disease. Dosing intervals and vaccine escape rates had smaller effects and were varied by 50% due to variability in the population and lack of characterization. Results suggested that effective vaccine deployment (ω1) was key in combating the pandemic, even with a less-than-ideal vaccine. Prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval, as done in Canada, could be beneficial if vaccine supply is limited. A sensitivity analysis of the full model with all three variants indicated that increasing key parameters had effects on the number of infections and deaths associated with each variant.

Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ), vaccination rate (ω1), delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 are varied by 5%. Since NPI are modelled by scaling βW directly, they have large effects on model predictions (Fig. 4). Vaccination rate has lesser but still significant effects on the spread of the disease. The effects of dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) are much smaller. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. In a second sensitivity analysis, we considered the full model that represents all three variants, using the baseline parameter values (Table S1). author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the number of new infections for various viruses from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021, represented as 7-day averages. It also shows the cumulative number of asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, the percentage of the population vaccinated with one or both doses, and the total number of deaths caused by each virus. Even small fluctuations (5%) in these parameters can lead to significant changes in infection rates and death tolls, as shown in Figure 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19 (μWI) impacts the number of infected individuals who are still alive and capable of spreading the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context:
delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βWV). λ and ω1 were both adjusted by 5% in the study. The impact of these changes on model predictions, particularly in relation to NPI, was significant as shown in Fig. 4. The rate of vaccination also played a role in the spread of the disease, although to a lesser extent. In contrast, dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βWV) had smaller effects. Given the potential variability in dosing intervals within a population and the lack of precise data on vaccine escape rates, these parameters were increased by 50%. The findings concerning vaccines indicated that effective deployment of a vaccine (as captured by ω1) is crucial for pandemic control, and success may still be possible even with a less effective vaccine with higher escape rates (Fig. 4).

The study highlighted that variations in ω1 had a more pronounced impact on predicted infection and death rates compared to variations in ω2. Therefore, if vaccine availability is constrained, prioritizing the first dose by extending the dosing interval, as seen in Canada, is a recommended strategy. A second sensitivity analysis was conducted using a comprehensive model representing all three variants, with adjustments made to key parameters to assess their effects on infection and death rates. This analysis included parameters related to VOC interactions, such as βXR and ηR, with distinct values for each variant.

Simulations were carried out by individually increasing the values of specific parameters for each variant, including βX (X = W, A, or D), σX, αX, γX, and ω1 by 5%, as well as increasing λ by 10%. An additional 4-fold increase in βXR was also conducted to evaluate its impact on the model. Lastly, ω2 was increased by 50% in the analysis.

author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the impact of different model parameter values on total infections and deaths in a two-year simulation of variant dynamics. Wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants are analyzed individually, with changes in infections and deaths calculated for each. Parameters such as virus infectivity, asymptomatic versus symptomatic ratio, and vaccine efficacy are explored. The model assumes a vaccine distribution similar to Ontario's, with Pfizer offering better protection against all variants, particularly Delta. Consideration is given to a scenario where a larger proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines are administered, as seen in the UK.For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a).The anticipated total number of Delta infections and related deaths by December 31, 2021 is projected to be significantly higher at 62K and 882 respectively, compared to the baseline values of 39K and 689. If the provincial vaccination rate falls to 67% by September 1, 2021, instead of the baseline 74%, the number of infections and deaths could increase by 75% by March 2022. Ontario began reopening gradually in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. Considering the possibility of pandemic fatigue and outbreaks in schools, the model assumes that the remaining NPIs will reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. However, there is concern that this assumption may be overly optimistic. As a result, a scenario with less stringent NPIs starting from September 1, 2021 is considered, with λ increased from its baseline value of 0.4.
original_pre_context: Figure 5.   Sensitivity of model predictions, measured by total infections and deaths, to increases in model parameter values, in a two-year simulation interacting VOC dynamics. Parameters are varied individually for wild-type (column a), Alpha (column b), and Delta (column c). Relative changes in the number of infections and deaths are then computed for wild-type (yellow bars), Alpha (red bars), and Delta (blue bars). Parameter examined include virus infectivity (β), rate of infection of individuals recovered from a different variant (βR), ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections (σ), degree of increased infectivity β (due to mobility) of asymptomatic infected individuals compared to symptomatic ones, mortality rate of infected individuals (μI), disease recovery rate (γ), rate of loss of immunity due to infection (ηR), vaccine escape rate (βV), NPI stringency (λ), dosing interval (ω2), vaccination rate (ω1). The baseline model assumes that 95% of the vaccines are Pfizer and 5% are AstraZeneca, consistent with Ontario vaccination statistics. What if a larger fraction of the vaccines were AstraZeneca, as is the case in the  UK18. A notable difference between the two vaccine types is that the Pfizer vaccine offers stronger protection than AstraZeneca against all COVID variants, especially Delta, after either one or two doses. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the end of 2021, the model predicts
original_post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The total number of Delta infections and related deaths are also significantly higher, predicted to be 62 K and 882 at the end of 2021, respectively, compared to baseline values of 39 K and 689 (Fig. 7b,d). If the provincial vaccination rate were lower, such that by September 1 2021 only 67% of the population are vaccinated with at least one dose, compared to the baseline vaccinated percentage of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would increase by 75% by the end of March 2022; see Fig. 7b,d. Beginning mid-June 2021, Ontario began to gradually reopen, with in-person classes set to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the NPI that remain will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. What if that assumption is overly optimistic? Indeed, it is not uncommon to experience pandemic fatigue and crave personal interactions; also, there may be outbreaks in schools. Thus, we consider a scenario with less stringent NPI starting from the fall of 2021 (September 1 2021), with λ increased from its baseline value of 0.4 Scientific Reports |         (2022) 12:2114  | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-022-06159-x 7 Vol.:(0123456789)www.nature.com/scientificreports/

Parameters include virus infectivity, rate of infection of recovered individuals, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, mortality rate, recovery rate, loss of immunity, vaccine escape rate, NPI stringency, dosing interval, and vaccination rate. However, if a larger fraction of AstraZeneca vaccines were administered, as seen in the UK, differences in vaccine efficacy are noted. Pfizer offers stronger protection against all variants, particularly Delta. For example, individuals vaccinated with both doses of Pfizer are 88% protected against Delta, while those vaccinated with AstraZeneca are only 60% protected.We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. Ontario began a gradual reopening in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) will continue to reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. What if this assumption is overly optimistic? pre_context:
Since January 23, 2020, there have been significant changes in control strategies for the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly affecting the contact rate, diagnose rate, and quarantine rate q. To maintain consistency with our previous study (Tang et al., 2020), we have kept all parameter values fixed except for these three. The initial contact rate c0 is calculated as the average rate between January 10 and January 22, 2020, which is 14.781. Similarly, we have set dI0 to 0.133 based on the same assumption. The initial conditions were determined by solving our previous model from January 10 to January 23, 2020. Using the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, we fitted the model to the data and utilized an adaptive Metropolis-Hastings algorithm with 70,000 iterations and a burn-in of 50,000 iterations. The Geweke convergence diagnostic method was used to evaluate chain convergence. The estimation results are presented in Table 1.

Following the lockdown of Hangzhou on January 23, 2020, travel restrictions have been implemented nationwide and advancements in nucleic acid-based detection technologies have enhanced case confirmation speed. With China's rigorous prevention and control measures and improved detection and treatment capabilities, the previously estimated basic reproduction number may no longer reflect the current epidemic trend accurately.Therefore, we use the updated data to parameterize the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-estimate the 2019-nCov transmission risk. To estimate the effective daily reproduction ratio, we initially get the time-dependent contact rate cðtÞ and dIðtÞ as Fig. 1(a). Using the discrete values of contact rate cðtÞ and diagnose rate dIðtÞ, we can calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio,

Under the scenario of adopting the strongest prevention and control strategy and improving the level of detection and treatment in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer suitable for evaluating the epidemic trend in the near future. Therefore, we use the updated data to parameterize the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-estimate the 2019-nCov transmission risk. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In comparison to the results shown in Fig. 2, we found a higher projected cumulative number of confirmed cases and a delayed peak time. Our previous article (Tang et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which is higher than other estimates. The WHO estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) calculated a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Other mathematical models have estimated the reproduction number to range from 1.3 to 4.7. Some studies within the literature have suggested an underestimation of coronavirus cases, such as research by Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020). Zhao et al. (2020) quantitatively assessed underreporting of coronavirus cases and estimated 469 underreported cases (95% CI 403e540), resulting in a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of their investigation, the reproduction number ranged between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10).The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Xiangyang there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections.The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13) with implications for public health suggesting that 58-76% of transmissions need to be blocked to halt the outbreak. Additional models incorporating data from international travel include those developed by Imai et al. (2020), Kucharski et al. (2020), and Wu et al. (2020). Imai et al. estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5) with variations depending on scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure ranging from 1.7 to 4.2. The reproduction number also fluctuated based on different estimates of generation time, from 1.3 to 4.3. Predictions and the impact of control measures on infection were analyzed assuming parameters obtained from data collected between January 23rd and January 29th, 2020 remain constant. Different scenarios included reducing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020 and altering the size of the susceptible population as of that date.
original_pre_context: omparison with the results in Fig. 2, we obtained higher projected cumulative confirmed cases and delayed peak time. Discussion In our previous article (Tang et al., 2020), we had estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which represents a higher value than those so far computed. For instance, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, Li and colleagues (Li et al., 2020) have computed a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9), while in several other mathematical models which have been so far devised and released as pre-prints or undergone peer-review and published, the reproduction number varies from 1.3 to 4.7. Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. Authors computed the number of under-reported coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540). Based on this estimate, the basic reproduction number was found to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Fig. 3 shows the optimal fitting of the model to the data on cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to February 1st, 2020. The projected numbers of infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed cases are displayed. The reproduction number, indicating infectiousness, ranged from 1.6 to 2.9. It was hypothesized that the novel virus would lead to more mild-to-moderate cases compared to the SARS virus, resulting in a reproduction number of 2.0 with uncertainty between 1.4 and 2.3. According to the study, public health interventions blocking over 60% of transmission would be necessary to effectively control the coronavirus outbreak. Various researchers have calculated different reproduction numbers and proposed varying levels of quarantine rates to contain the outbreak. Kucharski and team developed a stochastic SEIR model using the Euler-Maruyama algorithm with a 6-hour time-step and a transmission rate following geometric Brownian motion. They estimated the time-varying reproduction number using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach and utilized multiple datasets to provide real-time estimates while addressing data reliability concerns through Poisson probability calculations.Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. The study by Hubei and collaborators (Hubei et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a

(95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Hubei as of January 25th, 2020.The study by Shen and colleagues found that the epidemic's doubling time was 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1), with an estimated 8042 infections and 898 deaths, resulting in a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78). The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), decreasing to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) by January 22nd, 2020. It is predicted that the outbreak will significantly decrease within 77 days from its onset.

Additionally, Majumder and Mandl used the IDEA model to estimate the reproduction number as 2.0e3.1. Riou and Althaus calculated a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8) through a stochastic model, while Liu and colleagues estimated a value ranging from 2.90 to 2.92 using statistical techniques. Zhang and Wang inferred a time-calibrated phylogeny and found the most recent common ancestor to be on December 17th, 2019, with a reproduction number fluctuating between 1.1 and 1.6. These variations in findings may stem from different methodological approaches.

Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemics outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 [95% CI 75e80] days from its beginning. Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). Zhang and Wang (Zhang & Wang, 2020), employing a Bayesian framework to infer time-calibrated phylogeny from 33 available genomic sequences, found that the time of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was December 17th, 2019 (95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019) and that the value of the reproduction number oscillated between 1.1 and 1.6. These different findings may be due to several methodological issues, including different assumptions and choice of parameters, utilized models (stochastic versus deterministic, compartmental versus IDEA, etc.), used datasets and estimation period. Furthermore, by comparing the various updated versions of the above-mentioned investigations, the reproduction number was found to vary, reflecting the dynamics of transmission of the coronavirus outbreak as well as the dynamics of case reporting. More in detail, the reproduction number tended to increase over the time in parallel with the increase in cases bein

post_context: 1.56 7.65 0.25 0.580 0.001 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .Given the parameters used in our simulations as shown in Table 1, the basic reproductive number R0 is calculated to be 0.945. This indicates that the epidemic outbreak in Hubei was effectively controlled by the Chinese authorities. Moving on to local stability in relation to R0, it is observed that certain equations in the system are independent from the rest. By integrating these uncoupled equations, analytical results can be derived. Additionally, with a constant total population size N, the local stability of the model can be analyzed based on the remaining coupled variables E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables reveals key insights into the stability of the system, which can be further evaluated based on the characteristic polynomial and eigenvalues.

post_context: 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .By using the parameters outlined in Table 1, the basic reproduction number, R0, was calculated to be 0.945 in our simulations.
