text: the  total  human  population  size  at  time  t  denoted  as N(t)
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In a study conducted by Mwalili and colleagues...BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352 Page 2 of 5 non-linear  interactions  between  humans  and  the  environment;  and  (3)  thorough  simulation  studies  were performed. Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is labeled as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) applies. Research has demonstrated that the COVID-19 virus can spread in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to human. It has been observed from epidemic data that individuals infected with asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) they come into close contact with. Moreover, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without proper precautions, the virus can also spread to their surrounding environment. As the pathogen P(t) is capable of surviving in the environment for several days, individuals in close contact with this environment, especially during the initial stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are implemented, are at risk of exposure to these pathogens. The disease transmission process begins with susceptible individuals moving to the exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period. The exposed individuals then transition to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infectious populations. P(t) represents the number or quantity of pathogens present during human interactions at time t. The majority of infectious individuals recover and move to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is shown in Fig. 1. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1. This model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as depicted in the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission in Fig. 1.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili et al. (2020) conducted a study that focused on the complex interactions between humans and their environment, including thorough simulation studies. The study involved formulating a mathematical model to analyze the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. The model divided the human population into different categories based on their health status, such as susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. The virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact as well as from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, are known to spread the virus to susceptible persons they come into close contact with. Furthermore, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking precautions, the virus can spread into the environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at
post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).Figure 1 illustrates a compartmental model showing the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment. The parameters for the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1. This model results in a system of six-dimensional ordinary differential equations. See Figure 1 for the SEIR-P model depicting COVID-19 transmission, with a human (SEIR in yellow) and pathogen (P in green) compartmental model.

The  pathogen  in  the  environment  is denoted as P(t). Hence for the human population we have N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Studies have shown that the virus can be transmitted in  two  ways,  namely:  human  to  human  and  environment to human. The epidemic data indicates that both asymptomatic  IA(t)  and  symptomatic  IS(t)  infected individuals  spread  the  COVID-19  virus  to  susceptible persons  S(t)  with  whom  they  are  in  close  contact.  In addition,  when  infected  individuals  sneeze  or  cough, without  taking  the  necessary  precautions,  the  virus spreads to the environment they are in. Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population.  P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Figure 2 depicts the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model. Panel a shows the infectious case dynamics with varying levels of shielding (α), while panel b illustrates the final state of the system based on α. The model considers a transmission rate (β) of 0.25 and a recovery rate (γ) of 0.1. It is important to integrate interactions with patients in healthcare settings when implementing specific scenarios. Baseline epidemiological parameters, age-specific risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2 and in the code available on GitHub. To simulate outbreak scenarios, we use baseline epidemiological parameters and seed an outbreak with a single exposed individual until the prevalence reaches 0.1%. Different transmission rates are considered, with R0 values of 1.25 in low-transmission scenarios and 2.33 in high-transmission scenarios. Early estimates from Wuhan suggest an R0 range of 2.1 to 4.5.30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in India that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in India from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented.Figure 3 illustrates the impact of different shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of an epidemic by decreasing the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. In a population of the same size for a low-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths occur in individuals aged 60 years and older, even though they make up a smaller portion of the population. Our analysis focuses on the impact of shielding alone, while ongoing restrictions such as social distancing will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields. Population-scale effects of shielding are influenced by demographic distributions, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. Despite fewer recovered individuals between the ages of 20 and 60, they still contribute to the effectiveness of shielding efforts.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this research article, Zhao and Chen (2020) analyze the epidemic dynamics and control strategies of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The study highlights the unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as its high infectivity during incubation and the time delay between the actual spread of the virus and the reported number of confirmed cases. Additionally, the researchers discuss the impact of quarantine and control measures on controlling the spread of the virus. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Wuhan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Wuhan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Wuhan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Wuhan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, Wuhan had an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Using data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will end in Wuhan and Wuhan by late March, in the rest of China by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities by early March 2020. In total, there are estimated to be 80,511 infected individuals in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Wuhan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Wuhan). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. Recommendations: We advise maintaining strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Wuhan until late March. Our model can also help predict epidemic trends and provide guidance for countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran facing a high risk of outbreak. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and over 30 other countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model analyzes the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from China and can offer insights for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Email for correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn

Received: February 29, 2020
Revised: March 4, 2020
Accepted: March 4, 2020

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and to more than 30 countries within the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between the actual dynamics and the daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention efforts.

In this study, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly considers the effects of intervention measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to existing epidemic models.

Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hubei Province, China (excluding Hubei Province), and four major cities in China. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1, indicating rapid spread. However, after January 30, all regions had an R value less than 1, suggesting that quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hubei Province estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei Province on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei Province is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hubei Province, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided in the deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei Province until late March. This model can also be helpful in predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and over 30 countries, with unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation and a time delay in reporting confirmed cases. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and can offer guidance for other countries facing a potential outbreak.

After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
original_post_context: from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Accepted on March 4, 2020 Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the real dynamics versus daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

Methods: We have created a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and quantify the effects of control measures. This model is more appropriate for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: We applied the SUQC model to daily data on confirmed infections to analyze the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in Japan. Our findings show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number (R) less than 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. The findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Yokohama, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be valuable in predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, South Korea, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is currently spreading rapidly in Japan and numerous other countries. It possesses unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures. Our SUQC model was developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Japanese data to forecast the epidemic trajectory. It can also provide valuable insights for other countries facing a potential outbreak. (Copyright © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020)

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The data presented in Fig. 1B shows a significant disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed cases in Hubei Province, China. After February 12, clinical diagnosis was implemented as an additional criteria by the local medical authorities in Hubei Province, China, resulting in a higher confirmation rate and a surge in the number of confirmed cases. It is worth noting that despite clinical diagnosis, a portion of the total infected individuals remain unidentified. Using the inferred parameters, we have also generated long-term predictions for the numbers of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U), quarantined infected (Q), and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Hubei Province, China, as shown in Fig. 1A. The model predicts the outbreak to last 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals (Table 1). A similar analysis using the initial data from Hubei Province, China can provide insights into the epidemic trend in the absence of strict quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points from January 20 were used to estimate the parameters, while the remaining data points were used to validate the model's performance, as demonstrated in Fig. 1C, D. It is evident from Fig. 1C that the predicted numbers of C(t) and I(t) increase significantly, surpassing the observed numbers after January 21.The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hubei Province, China and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context: , indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). We conducted a similar analysis on stage I and II data from Hubei province (excluding Hubei Province, China), the entire country (excluding Hubei Province, China), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions were highly accurate, showing distinct trends in infected numbers between the different regions. Beijing, even with stage I data, had a reproductive number below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19. The confirmation rate in Hubei Province, China was the lowest compared to other regions, with a significant number of quarantined infections remaining unconfirmed until clinical diagnosis was implemented. The quarantine and reproductive numbers also varied among the different stages and regions analyzed.

With stricter quarantine measures and traffic controls being put in place, the epidemic in Wuhan is estimated to end sooner with a higher quarantine rate and a lower total number of infected individuals. Similar analyses have been conducted for other regions in China, showing comparable trends and emphasizing the necessity of quarantine and control measures. Overall, the model predictions have been accurate, highlighting the importance of early and effective responses to the COVID-19 outbreak.From Figs. 2 and 3, Supplementary Figs. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between CðtÞ and IðtÞ in Wuhan is the biggest. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: After January 21, the number of total infected individuals could reach up to 8,923,823 with the epidemic lasting for 328 days. The significant difference between predictions from stage I and stage II data by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen suggests that preventative measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, have effectively controlled the outbreak of the epidemic. Recent stricter quarantine and traffic control measures in Beijing, along with the adoption of clinical diagnosis after February 12, has led to an analysis of stage III data from February 13. The estimated quarantine rate is now 0.6185, higher than the 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data, with a projected total number of infected individuals at 49,510, indicating a hastening of the epidemic's end. Similar analyses have been conducted on stage I and II data for Hubei province (excluding Beijing), the rest of the country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions have shown high accuracy, revealing consistent trends across these regions in terms of the impact of quarantine and control measures. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between CðtÞ and IðtÞ in Beijing is the biggest. Beijing has the most infected individuals than any other places in China (more than 50%), highly beyond the limit of local clinical resources, leading to a long waiting time for confirmation, and the lowest confirmation rate of 0.0643 in Beijing, compared with 0.1914 of Hubei (excluding Beijing), 0.2189 of China (excluding Hubei), 0.2680 of Beijing,

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The number of total infected individuals could reach up to 8,923,823 after Jan 21, with the epidemic lasting for a longer period of 328 days (refer to Table 1). The significant disparity in predictions between stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data suggests that preventive measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, have been highly effective in controlling the outbreak of the epidemic. With stricter quarantine and traffic control measures implemented post Feb 12 to curb the spread of COVID-19 in Wuhan, including the adoption of clinical diagnosis, an analysis of stage III data (from Feb 13) was conducted. A higher estimated quarantine rate of 0.6185 was observed compared to the 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data, with the total number of infected individuals estimated to be 49,510, indicating a faster deceleration of the epidemic (refer to Table 1). Similar analyses were carried out on stage I and II data of Hubei province (excluding Wuhan), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China, revealing a high level of accuracy in the model predictions. Consistent trends were observed across these regions, where the projected numbers of infected individuals differed significantly between the two stages of data, emphasizing the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Notably, even with stage I data, Beijing displayed a reproductive number of less than 1 (refer to Supplementary Fig. S1; Table 2, 0.8840), indicating a swift and efficient response to COVID-19 at an early stage.

From Figs. 2 and 3, Supplementary Figs. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between CðtÞ and IðtÞ in Wuhan is the biggest. Wuhan has the most infected individuals than any other places in China (more than 50%), highly beyond the limit of local clinical resources, leading to a long waiting time for confirmation, and the lowest confirmation rate of 0.0643 in Wuhan, compared with 0.1914 of Hubei (excluding Wuhan), 0.2189 of China (excluding Hubei), 0.2680 of Beijing, 0.2846 of Shanghai,
post_context: of Shenzhen, and 0.2599 of Shenzhen. According to the model, it was estimated that there were 26,810 unconfirmed infections under quarantine in Wuhan as of Feb 11, 2020. The confirmation rate in Wuhan increased to 0.3229 after Feb 12 when clinical diagnosis was implemented. The table shows parameter estimations for epidemic dynamics in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and China (excluding Hubei), including quarantine rate, reproductive number, and confirmation rate. The end time for each stage is based on specific criteria.

post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5).This results in a higher reproductive number (R=α=g1). The reproductive number in Huanggang drops from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III. Based on these numbers, it appears that the epidemic in China is generally under control, except for un-quarantined individuals who are the main source of new infections. According to data from stage II, there are still an estimated 3,509 infected individuals in Huanggang as of February 12. Person-to-person transmission is expected to continue until mid-May 2020. However, data from stage III shows that the quarantine rate in Huanggang has increased to 0.6185, resulting in a decrease in unquarantined infected individuals to 334 by February 21, 2020. Predictions made after analyzing data from stages II and III suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China may end in late March, with the four first-tier cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen reaching the end before early March. The end of the outbreak may be sooner when considering zero un-quarantined infections compared to zero new confirmed cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account, models allow for each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed probability distribution, with the variance potentially depending on the mean. While a lack of data is a significant concern for modellers, one key issue influencing model predictions is how the available data of confirmed cases aligns with these predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been tested and confirmed to have COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all individuals who are infected, whether symptomatic or not, and may or may not have confirmed tests. This distinction between confirmed cases (data) and model predictions is likened to an iceberg, with the tip above the surface representing data and the bulk hidden beneath symbolizing the unknown portion of the infected population - a concept known as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate important parameters like the transmission rate (b) by comparing model output to confirmed cases data, it is crucial to adjust for the total number of infectious people (I(t)) in the model prediction using the case-infection ratio (r) to accurately predict confirmed cases. By varying the ratio r, different values for the transmission rate b can be calculated to determine the basic reproduction number (R0), epidemic scale, and peak time. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range as well, leading to a variety of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, means that multiple combinations of r and b can fit the data well but produce vastly different epidemic predictions. How nonidentifiability is handled in model calibration significantly impacts the reliability of predictions. Traditional nonlinear least squares methods may struggle to address nonidentifiability since they use basic optimization algorithms that aim to find a global minimum of the objective function, resulting in many possible solutions.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Shanghai, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Shanghai, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment known as E represents individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. This concept is biologically realistic, as COVID-19 has an incubation period of up to 14 days during which newly infected individuals may not be infectious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to symptom onset. For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, leading to a longer average latent period compared to the incubation period. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can be infectious before showing symptoms, though the length of the latent period remains unknown. The SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, but it requires additional parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. The differential equations for both models are shown in Figure 1, with detailed parameter meanings in Table 1 and Table 2. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the predictive period (4 months). The models are calibrated using newly confirmed case data, matching the rI term in both models, with deaths in the R compartment having no impact on fitting. The equations for both models are given as follows: S' = βIS, I' = βIS - (r + m)I, R' = rI, E' = βIS - εE, I' = εE - (r + m)I, R' = rI. To ensure data reliability, calibration is based on the most recent and accurate data available.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative sources, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. To address this, improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms can help narrow down large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, utilizing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

For our baseline predictions for Huangshi, we used prediction intervals generated by sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals, with Bayesian inference relying on newly confirmed cases in Huangshi from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These predictions represent the epidemic in Huangshi during the lockdown before further control measures were implemented after February 7, such as increased hospital beds and door-to-door visits for quarantine. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time distributions and estimated control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Huangshi together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimate, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7th, the number of peak cases is projected to reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Huangshi would extend until mid-May of 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.
original_post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. By our projection, without the strict quarantine measures after February 7, the peak case total would reach approximately 120; 000, and the epidemic in Wuhan would not be over before mid-May of 2020.

If a realistic network structure is included (households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the transmission rate (β) varies depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 chosen to match data from time-use surveys and infection studies. Without interventions, the distribution of transmission events is roughly 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions like physical distancing can modify the value of β. Additionally, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness, with individual viral load used to model differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load informs the adjustment of per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameters. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary based on the situation, as demonstrated by estimates for Seattle [25]. There is uncertainty regarding whether transmission is less likely if the infected person is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we allow for adjustments based on the modeling scenario or setting, acknowledging that some studies have suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
original_pre_context: 2]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals given default parameter values are shown in Fig 2. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25]. Evidence is mixed as to whether transmissibility is lower if the infectious individual does not have symptoms [55]. We take a default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be modified as needed depending on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
